title: Lobster Abundance
description: The effects of marine protected areas on lobster abundance
contents:
Introduction
In 2012, California signed into law the Marine Life Protection Act which created a series of underwater parks to preserve California’s marine ecosystems for future generations to enjoy (Santa Barbara Channel Keeper 2019). These Marine Protected Areas (MPAs) restrict fishing within them and allow for the development of marine ecosystems absent harmful anthropogenic influences. Since the establishment of MPAs, the Santa Barbara Coastal Long Term Ecological Research program has been collecting data on the size and abundance of the California Spiny Lobster Panilus interruptus at five locations along the mainland coast of the Santa Barbara Channel (Reed 2018). The California spiny lobster is an important constituent of the Giant Kelp Forest ecosystem in the Santa Barbara Channel. Their predation of sea urchins helps to maintain a healthy balance of organisms on the seabed and prevent unsustainable losses of kelp. By locating just two of the survey sites in or near MPAs, the SBC LTER has made it possible to estimate the effect of fishing pressure on the spiny lobster over the past seven years by tracking trends in lobster abundance and size.
Data and Methods
Data collection took place in late summer annually at five sites (Arroyo Quemado, Carpinteria, Isla Vista, Mohawk, and Naples) two of which (IVEE and Naples) are within MPAs. 4,362 individual observations were recorded. Our variables of interest were the number of lobsters recorded at each site and a visual estimate of carapace size in millimeters. Abundance was visualized with a line graph to view the population trajectories of all five sites. A density plot was used to visualize community size structure in the first and last year of study. A series of Welch two-sample t-tests were performed to determine if there was an observable difference in mean lobster size between four different groupings (MPA sites in 2012 and 2018 and non-MPA sites in 2012 and 2018). A significance level of .05 was used for our hypothesis testing. The data was analyzed with RStudio Version 1.2.1335.
Results
1. Spiny Lobster abundance along the Santa Barbara coast
Spiny lobster population trends were compared across five long term ecological research study sites over a period of seven years. Two of the sites (Naples and Isla Vista) were located in or near the California Fish and Game Network of Marine Protected Areas (MPA). These two sites followed a similar trajectory for the first four years of the survey after which they diverge drastically with Isla Vista jumping up to 606 individuals in 2017 and Naples dropping to 112 in the same year. Of the remaining sites, Carpinteria had the most dynamic sample population count shown by its jump from 231 to 705 individuals followed by an immediate fall to 343 all in the last three years of study. Mohawk saw a dramatic increase from 2014 to 2015 followed by a slow steady decline and Arroyo Quemado was the most stable of all populations sampled.












2. Lobster Size Distribution Shifts
To track possible changes in the distribution of lobster sizes over time, we compared the data from the first year of study (2012) with the most recent data (2018). Little change in size distributions was observed from the three sites not located within a Marine Protected Area. While the shape of their distribution curves vary slightly between years, median size values were not different in a meaningful way. The two sites located within an MPA (Isla Vista and Naples) demonstrated a visible shift in their size distributions between the two years. Median sizes for those sites increased markedly between 2012 and 2018 as visualized by single quantile lines. This indicates a shift in community size structure to larger lobsters in the Marine Protected Areas.



3. Comparing Mean Lobster Sizes at MPA vs Non MPA sites
Four seperate Welch two-sample t-tests (α = 0.05) were run to estimate whether there was a significant difference in mean size (mm) among lobster groupings. The results of those tests are below:
MPA sites vs. Non-MPA sites in 2012 There was a significant difference in means (p=0.03)
MPA sites vs. Non-MPA sites in 2018 There was a significant difference in means (p<0.005)
MPA sites in 2012 vs. MPA sites in 2018 There was a significant difference in means (p<0.005)
Non-MPA sites in 2012 vs Non-MPA sites in 2018 There was no significant difference in means (p=0.323)





















Summary statistics for the four lobster data groupings are shown below in Table 1. Note the large discrepancy in sample sizes across the site data. There were only just enough observations for the MPA sites in 2012 (n=32) to state comfortably that the lobster size data are normally distributed in that sample. This coupled with the fact that there were nearly forty times more observations for MPA sites in 2018 (n=1244.0) casts doubt on how meaningul our findings of statistical significance was for the difference of means between both groups. Although the results also indicate a statistically significant difference in means between MPA and unprotected sites in 2018, the actual difference was only four millimeters, less than half the standard deviations within each group.


Table 1: Table 1. Descriptive statistics of lobster size data


Metrics


MPA 2012


MPA 2018


Unprotected 2012


Unprotected 2018


Mean (mm)


67.4


77.6


74.9


73.6


Std. Deviation (mm)


12.2


11.7


12.4


10.1


Sample Size


32.0


1244.0


199.0


561.0


Summary
Lobster abundance has seen its most dramatic changes in the past three years, with MPA sites experiencing large gains in population and non-MPA sites having stagnant or decreasing populations as shown in Figure 1.
Median size for lobsters in MPAs increased over the course of the study while median size for lobsters not in MPAs remained the same as shown in Figure 2.
There is a small difference in mean size between lobster groupings located within an MPA in 2018 and lobster groupings not within an MPA in 2018 though it is likely to be trivial.
References
Reed D. 2019. SBC LTER: Reef: Abundance, size and fishing effort for California Spiny Lobster (Panulirus interruptus), ongoing since 2012. Environmental Data Initiative. https://doi.org/10.6073/pasta/a593a675d644fdefb736750b291579a0
Santa Barbara Channel Keeper https://www.sbck.org/current-issues/marine-conservation/marine-protected-areas/learn-about-mpas/ Marine Conservation - Learn about MPAs. Accessed on 11/14/19

title: Spatial Data Visualization
contents:
#Read in Oil Spill Data
oil_spill <- read_sf(here("_posts", "Oil_Spill_Incident_Tracking_%5Bds394%5D-shp"), layer = "Oil_Spill_Incident_Tracking_%5Bds394%5D") %>% 
  clean_names() %>% 
  rename(county = localecoun)





#Read in California County Boundaries
ca_county <- read_sf(here("_posts", "ca_counties"), layer = "CA_Counties_TIGER2016"
) %>% 
  clean_names()

#Set county crs to same as oil spill
ca_county <- st_transform(ca_county, st_crs(oil_spill))





#looking at inland spills counts per county
inland <- oil_spill %>% 
  filter(inlandmari == "Inland")

ca_inland <- ca_county %>% 
  st_join(inland)

inland_spill <- ca_inland %>% 
  count(county)
 
ggplot(data = inland_spill) +
  geom_sf(aes(fill = n), color = "white", size = 0.1) +
  scale_fill_gradientn(colors = c("lightgray","darkorange","darkred")) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(fill = "Number of Oil Spills",
       title = "Density of California Oil Spills by County")

title: Spatial Data Visualization
contents:
#Read in Oil Spill Data
oil_spill <- read_sf(here("_posts", "oil_spill", "Oil_Spill_Incident_Tracking_%5Bds394%5D-shp"), layer = "Oil_Spill_Incident_Tracking_%5Bds394%5D") %>% 
  clean_names() %>% 
  rename(county = localecoun)





#Read in California County Boundaries
ca_county <- read_sf(here("_posts", "ca_counties"), layer = "CA_Counties_TIGER2016"
) %>% 
  clean_names()

#Set county crs to same as oil spill
ca_county <- st_transform(ca_county, st_crs(oil_spill))





#looking at inland spills counts per county
inland <- oil_spill %>% 
  filter(inlandmari == "Inland")

ca_inland <- ca_county %>% 
  st_join(inland)

inland_spill <- ca_inland %>% 
  count(county)
 
ggplot(data = inland_spill) +
  geom_sf(aes(fill = n), color = "white", size = 0.1) +
  scale_fill_gradientn(colors = c("lightgray","darkorange","darkred")) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(fill = "Number of Oil Spills",
       title = "Density of California Oil Spills by County")

title: Text and Sentiment Analysis
contents:
Read in text of Songs of the Cattle Trail and Cow Camp.


cowboys_text <- pdf_text("cowboys.pdf")



Check to see one of the pages.


cowboys34 <- cowboys_text[34]

cowboys34


[1] "it wa'n't no joke.\nBut the stranger moven' no muscle as he looked in\nthe bore of Bill's gun;\nHe hadn't no thought to stir, sir; he hadn't no\nthought to run;\nBut he spoke out cool and quiet, \" I might live for\na thousand year\nAnd not die at last so nobly as defendin' this\nGreaser here;\nFor he's wounded, now, and helpless, and hasn't\nhad no fair show;\nAnd the first of ye boys that strikes him, I'll lay\nthat first one low.\"\nThe gang respected the stranger that for another\nwas willing to die;\nThey respected the look of daring they saw in that\ncold, blue eye.\n12\nThe Texas Cowboy and the Mexican Greaser\n"

Change it to a tidy dataframe.


cowboy_tidy <- data.frame(cowboys_text) %>% 
  mutate(text_full = str_split(cowboys_text, pattern = '\\n')) %>% 
  unnest(text_full) %>% 
  mutate(text_full = str_trim(text_full))



Take out all the introductory pages that don’t have cowboy songs.


cowboy_df <- cowboy_tidy %>% 
  slice(-(1:370))



Give a new row for each word.


cowboy_tokens <- cowboy_df %>% 
  unnest_tokens(word, text_full) %>% 
  dplyr::select(-cowboys_text)



Count all the words up and eliminate all the numbers in the beginning.


cowboy_wordcount <- cowboy_tokens %>% 
  count(word) %>% 
  slice(-(1:155))



Time to remove stop words.


cowboy_nonstop_words <- cowboy_tokens %>% 
  anti_join(stop_words)



Recount them and get rid of the page numbers


nonstop_counts <- cowboy_nonstop_words %>% 
  count(word) %>% 
  slice(-(1:154))



Let’s look at the top 100 words used in Songs of the Cattle Trail and Cow Camp.


top_100_words <- nonstop_counts %>% 
  arrange(-n) %>% 
  slice(1:100) 



Some cowboy specific stop words snuck through to this step so we’re going to manually eliminate them. They are: til, em, fer, yer, git, o’er, yo, thar, and twas. Leaves us with the 91 most used non-stop words.


top_words <- top_100_words %>% 
  slice(-c(4,5,6,16,43,45,49,53,88))



Let’s make a word cloud for Songs of the Cattle Trail and Cow Camp.


cowboy_cloud <- ggplot(data = top_words, aes(label = word)) +
  geom_text_wordcloud(aes(color = n, size = n), shape = "circle") +
  scale_size_area(max_size = 8) +
  scale_color_gradientn(colors = c("brown","yellow","red")) +
  theme_minimal()

cowboy_cloud




Trail is the most frequently used word in the book
Surprisingly there are no yeehaws

Time to do sentiment analysis on frequently used cowboy words


cowboy_afinn <- top_words %>% 
  inner_join(get_sentiments("afinn"))





# Plot them: 
ggplot(data = cowboy_afinn, aes(x = value, y = n, fill = word)) +
  geom_col() +
  labs(x = "Sentiment Values", y = "Number of Uses", title = "Most frequent sentimental words in Songs of the Cattle Trail and Cowcamp") +
  theme_minimal()




A lot of love in cowboy songs, it’s the most frequently used sentimental word
The most common negative words by far were about death. Cowboys also have to contend with things that broke (or perhaps being broke financially), getting cut, and fighting.
Source Citation: Lomax, Alan. Songs of the Cattle Trail and Cow Camp. Duell, Sloan, and Pearce, 1909. Google Books, source:“http://books.google.com/books?id=XqnNYZW9olsC&oe=UTF-8”.

title: Climatic Principle Components Analysis
description: PCA on four global climate variables for 243 countries.
contents:
Describe the data and the variables I will be exploring.
The dataset that I’m using for principle component analysis is a set of environmental and climatic variables for 243 countries that was compiled using the Google Earth Engine. While the original data frame has 27 different variables for each country, I’ve chosen to focus on and explore the relationships between four of them to see how they may influence one another. I’m going to evaluate the interactions of mean annual rainfall, percentage of cropland cover, percentage of tree canopy cover, and isothermality (annual mean temperature/mean monthly temperature range).
Data citation: Gorelick, N., Hancher, M., Dixon, M., Ilyushchenko, S., Thau, D., & Moore, R. (2017). Google Earth Engine: Planetary-scale geospatial analysis for everyone. Remote Sensing of Environment.
Read in the global climate data and wrangle to set up for principle components analysis.


world_data <- read_csv(here("_posts", "2021-02-12-welcome", "data", "world_env_vars.csv")) %>% 
  clean_names() %>% 
  select(cropland_cover, tree_canopy_cover, rain_mean_annual, isothermality) %>% 
  rename(Crop.Cover = cropland_cover) %>% 
  rename(Tree.Canopy.Cover = tree_canopy_cover) %>% 
  rename(Mean.Annual.Rainfall = rain_mean_annual) %>% 
  rename(Isothermality = isothermality) %>% 
  drop_na() %>% 
  scale() %>% 
  prcomp

world_complete <- read_csv(here("_posts", "2021-02-12-welcome", "data", "world_env_vars.csv")) %>% 
  drop_na(cropland_cover, tree_canopy_cover, rain_mean_annual, isothermality) %>% 
  clean_names()

world_pca <- autoplot(world_data,
         data = world_complete,
         colour = "ivory4",
         loadings = TRUE,
         loadings.colour = "green",
         loadings.label = TRUE,
         loadings.label.hjust = 1.1)
  theme_minimal() +
    theme(legend.position = FALSE)


List of 93
 $ line                      :List of 6
  ..$ colour       : chr "black"
  ..$ size         : num 0.5
  ..$ linetype     : num 1
  ..$ lineend      : chr "butt"

world_pca




Give the World PCA plot a nice caption


world_pca




Figure 1: Figure 1. Princple components analysis exploring relationships between isothermality, mean annual rainfall, tree canopy cover, and crop cover for 231 countries.



Summary of PCA exploration
Mean annual rainfall is positively correlated with tree canopy cover.
This was unsurprising as I expected additional rainfall to be associated with greater tree canopy cover.

Crop cover is uncorrelated with mean annual rainfall and tree canopy cover
This was somewhat surprising as I expected crop cover and mean annual rainfall to be correlated. That may have been the case historically but I suppose in most places today crops are artificially irrigated and not dependent on rainfall.

Isothermality is slightly negatively correlated with crop cover.
Interesting because in essence what this means is that when you have a greater level of temperature fluctuations relative to the annual fluctuation, cropland coverage is expected to decrease. This makes sense because crops tend to like consistent temperatures within a relatively narrow range. When you have large fluctuations, you’re less likely to have productive fields.

83% of the variance in the data is captured by the evaluating these four variables.
